issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

fields.summary: Date header in HTTP responses uses the wrong time zone

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When a CLC rejects a request due to clock skew, it might be useful to add its current time to the error response somehow so the user can plainly see how far off his or her clock is.

AWS does this with the {{Date}} header that happens to be in all of its responses anyway.
fields.summary: Clock skew errors should mention the server's current time

comments.body:
Hi [~sjones]

Quick question on this one, should I just add the 'Date" header in NioHandler:sendError(). I played around with adding a marshallException() method to QueryTimestampHandler (also making it implement ExceptionMarshallerHandler), which will only return the Date header on time expiration type errors. Wondering if we should just add the Date header to all errors. 

Thanks,
-Steve
[~sgraham], we should include a "Date" header in all responses. Feel free to add a Date header in whatever way makes sense to address this issue.

Hi [~sjones]

Yeah I started with adding it to all then found out that the error code path is different. I'll go ahead and put it in both places so we have it in all responses. Thanks.

-Steve

[~sgraham],

I would use "new Date()" rather than "Calendar.getInstance().getTime()" as the construction of a calendar is not necessary.

MappingHttpResponse is used for both inbound and outbound response messages, it is not appropriate to add headers to an inbound response. We should add some documentation if we will have different behaviour for inbound vs. outbound constructors. I'm not sure the date should be set when the response is constructed or when it is sent, but if setting at construction time I would use MappingHttpMessage#getTimestamp for the value.

Hi [~sjones],

I changed the approach here to actually just create a HttpResponseHeaderHandler that gets put into the server pipeline and adds the Date header on outgoing responses. This seems like a cleaner solution than mucking with MappingHttpResponse. 

According to Amazon the 'Date' header is defined as the date in which the server responded. I kept both of responses (from the handler, and sendError()) to just use {{new Date()}} as the timestamp. 

My changes are in the branch: dev-sgraham-EUCA-5627 commit 11dd263a

Let me know if that looks good.

Thanks,
Steve

[~sgraham], looks good to me, though in the handler I would recommend checking if there is a date header and setting only if not present. Some pipelines do set the date header and although it seems safe to overwrite I would avoid doing so. If you do make changes you could switch to the correct license header for new files (not worth making changes for otherwise)

Code was reviewed by [~sjones].

Latest change was to not modify the header if it already existed, and add the appropriate license to the file. 

Merged to master:
Commit: 6a0821f
